dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crickets. A spring night in rural Virginia. MILDRED(18) seems nervous. Her eyes cast down. She’s beautiful. A slender, light skinned black woman. High cheekbones hint at a mix of Native American ancestry. She picks her head up and takes a deep breath. Her big br eyes are soft in the light of the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m pregnant. RICHARD(24) listens. He’s a white man with close cropped blonde hair and a dark neck burned from working outside. He takes in the information. A smile breaks across his face, revealing a mouth full of crooked teeth. He quickly draws his lips over them, swallowing the smile. He’s shy, self-conscious of the tee He begins to nod, a more reserved smile coming through.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Good. That’s real good. At this, Mildred’s shoulders drop with relief. They sit close to one another on the front steps of a one story wood planked house. It’s 1958. They are young, but a rural working life makes them seem older than their years. Richard takes her hand. She leans into him. An ominous SOUND grows in the distance. A rumbling like thunder. It builds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chassis on an early 50’s Chevy rocks back and forth a gas charges through the idling motor. VIRGIL(25) continues to rev the car as he steals a glance his competition, another bulked up American machine prime explode off the starting line. Virgil is a mustached black man with thick eyebrows. He wears a bowler hat and clinches a toothpick in his teeth. catches the OTHER DRIVER’s eye, a white man. Virgil smile  A Man snaps a rag into the air. Tires smoke. Rubber streaks the asphalt as the cars light out down the strip. Richard pops off the hood of a parked car and tracks the race. He’s part of a GROUP gathered on the dirt swath tha borders the track. Mildred is with her sister GARNET(20), a woman of similar features and beauty. The Group of seven is made up of bla and whites. Most hold cans of beer. All follow the race. The two cars race neck and neck, their chrome bumpers straining for the lead. Virgil’s car manages to pull ahea Standing by Richard are RAYMOND(20), a thick-necked black who is easy to smile when not sweating a race, and PERCY( a tall man who watches more than he talks. At Virgil’s ca taking the lead, Raymond’s hand comes up.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: There goes. The other Driver leans into the wheel as if to aid his chances, but it doesn’t help. Virgil manages a car length lead as he tears across the finish line. He yells and punches at the roof. Richard’s arm flies up, but he’s silent. Raymond lets out whooping sound before swinging out his massive palm which Richard meets with a slap. The Group cheers behind them. Richard walks back to Mildred, but on his way...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Timing’s still off ‘bout two degrees.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Looked fine to me. (to Percy) What you think?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: I think we won. Mildred runs up and gives Richard a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgil and Percy stand in front of the other Driver and h CREW, all white, as the Driver counts a stack of cash out places it in Virgil’s outstretched bowler hat.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: Now that’s just fine right there, I told them ‘bout ya’ll that you boys have ya’ll’s, yes keep on now, you boys have a fast car right there but ya’ll is fine to let us race wit you. Virgil's words come out in a jumble, making their meaning nearly imperceptible though their intention is clear. The money counted, Virgil sets the cash filled hat on his head and nods at the other Driver. He cuts a smile at Per before they turn back to join their own group. The disgruntled men rest against their beaten car. Their attention is not on Virgil’s collection, but rather on Richard and Mildred across the track. Richard holds Mildred close, kissing her proudly. The Cre just stares across at them, visibly seething.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hillbilly house party in full swing. A few cars come and go, but most are parked in an array around the yard. People spill out of the tiny house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shack is brimming with bodies, thick smoke and booze. Laughter and shouts fill in amidst fast paced fiddles, ba and upright bass pounding out a bluegrass stomp. The crowd is mostly black, though a few whites are mingle throughout. Many look to be Native American. Richard, his arm around Mildred, clutches a beer and struggles to shout his point into Raymond’s ear. An inaudible reply from Raymond brings a red faced gut laugh from Richard. Percy looks over to see what was so funny. Virgil bumps through the crowd half dancing while careful balancing his jar of clear liquor. He bows the drink to Mildred, but Garnet’s hand swoops in to take it. Garnet wags a finger before taking an eyebrow raising si the stout stuff. She eyes Mildred, who smiles back at her Virgil pulls Garnet up to dance not forgetting to reclaim drink. He proceeds to dance in a way that spreads the cro Mildred nudges Richard. They laugh watching their friends dance, happy in this pl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mortar is thrown onto a brick and buttered with a jointer before another brick comes down on top. It’s a rhythmic task, done with precision. Richard stands in front of a growing wall amongst several OTHER MEN laying brick at a bustling job site.

dialogues.speaker: BRICKLAYER
dialogues.text: Damn Richard. Slow down. Richard smiles to himself. He finishes out his course of bricks and quickly gathers his tools. Walking away...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: All right now.

dialogues.speaker: BRICKLAYER
dialogues.text: Where you goin’? Richard doesn’t answer. He moves toward a collection of c parked nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light breeze moves through full summer leaves shading a hillside. Grass bends in a low-lying field down below. Richard’s feet move heel to toe, counting out a length. Still in his work clothes, he pauses and stares out at th field down below before finally turning to Mildred. Time has passed since seeing her last. A growing belly sh six months of her pregnancy. She watches him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here. This spot.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You mean this field?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: This field not a mile from my house that I’ve been knowin’ all my life?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. She cocks her head at him, puzzled by this.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yes. I like it. Richard breaks away and faces the lower field again.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I'd put the kitchen back here.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Richard stop this. I don’t know what you’re sayin’.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I bought it. This whole acre. I’m gonna build you a house right here. Our house. Mildred is speechless. Her eyes wander over the ground as seeing it for the first time. She barely notices Richard move close, taking her hand. Her eyes finally meet his. He looks serious.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mildred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feet rushing through tall grass, dodging in and out and brambles. Mildred, as best she can carrying the extra weight, through a grove of trees. 7 of limbs darts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tobacco field is vast, bordered on one side by a thic of trees and falling off to a horizon on the other. The sun is quickly setting behind the field, but a DOZEN PEOPLE, black and white, still toil there. They slouch ov the plants, weeding grass from between thick green leaves Mildred emerges from the thicket of trees, moving fast. S rushes into the field weaving between rows. Garnet barely straightens before Mildred has grabbed her the hand and pulls her away from her work.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: What’s this now? Garnet is led out of the field back into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fireflies have begun to rise in the grove. Mildred is tuc against a tree in the midst of a whisper to her sister.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Said he'd bought it for me. And then he asked me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: No he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yes. Mildred’s hand covers her mouth trying to contain her excitement.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: Right out in the field? Oh Lord that man might be crazy. When you gonna do it?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: He didn’t say. Soon though. Before the baby comes. Garnet’s eyes move upward as she takes in a long breath. seems troubled.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: He’s gonna take my sister from me.  10 11

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: No. We'll be right down the road. Garnet takes Mildred’s hand and holds it to her face. Mildred smiles, which leads her sister to as well. They giggle at one another as evening takes hold. EXT. LOLA’S HOUSE - DAY 10 Chickens peck the morning dew in the yard around a tin ro shack. This is one in a collection of houses built togeth in a small community. Richard’s car pulls in next to a rusty pickup. He climbs as LOLA(48), a weathered woman already missing teeth, hel very pregnant WHITE GIRL(17) out of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hey Momma.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: They out back.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Here now. Richard grabs the young Girl’s hand to help her down the porch steps. On the ground, she heads to the pickup.

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT GIRL
dialogues.text: Thank you Miss Lola. We’1ll see you soon.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: We'll be here. As Richard moves around to the back of the house, the Gir cranks up the pickup and rattles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wooden barn has a poured concrete floor showing its conversion to a makeshift garage. The walls are lined wit tools and parts. Raymond takes a bite from a bologna sandwich before ducki under the hood of their Chevy race car parked inside. Richard walks in and surveys the work.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How we doin’?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that board and get up under there. See if you can’t get this manifold loose. Richard snags a roller board and wrench from the corner a slides on his back under the front end. The two work in tandem, Raymond from above, Richard from below. They work in silence for awhile. Then...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m gonna take Mildred up to D.C. to get married. Raymond takes this in, but doesn’t stop working.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Raymond lifts the part out and carries it to a table.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Hold on, stay under there. Raymond returns with another piece that he drops under th hood. Richard, with no need for explanation, grabs the pi and starts to affix it to the car.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need a witness?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. I was gonna ask her Dad to come with us. As they continue to work, Virgil enters the barn. He immediately finds Raymond’s sandwich. He picks it up and smells it.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Rich is gonna take Mildred up to D.C. to get married. Virgil takes a bite. With a full mouth...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: String Bean? That don’t make no damn sense.  12 13 Virgil chunks the rest of the sandwich into a metal bin a walks back out of the garage. Trailing off...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'd be livin’ up in da house wit no wife jus’ fine ‘fore you'd... Virgil is gone before concluding his thought. Richard, st tucked under the car, smiles to himself. I/E. RICHARD’S CAR/HIGHWAY TO D.C. - DAY 12 Richard drives on the open highway with the windows down music drifting from the radio. Mildred sits up front next him. They wear their finest clothes. Mildred’s father, THEOLIVER “Jake”(52), rides quietly in backseat. He wears a suit and hat.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You think they’1l see us today?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I called up there.

dialogues.speaker: THEOLIVER
dialogues.text: Seem like a long drive to me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming Jake.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Daddy what’s the city like? Theoliver shrugs, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: THEOLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Mildred stand in front of a MAGISTRATE in the courthouse office. Theoliver stands behind them. Richard slips a slight gold band on Mildred’s finger. She smiles at him, her round belly filling the altered church dress.

dialogues.speaker: MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: By the power vested in me by the District of Columbia, I now pronounce you husband and wife.  14 Al4 10. Richard and Mildred kiss. INT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE - KITCHEN - NIGHT 14 Garnet studies Mildred’s ring as their mother, MUSIEL(46) sits at the table snapping beans.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: I may not forgive him.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Come on now.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: You lucky if I forgive you. No reason to go all the way up there for this and not take us.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: We took Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: Like that means a thing.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Richard said there was less red tape in Washington. That’s all. Garnet, not convinced, tosses Mildred’s hand back at her grabs a fistful of beans to snap. Mildred’s eyes go back the ring.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: You can stop lookin’ at it String Bean, you know it’s pretty. Mildred smiles at her sister, using the edge of the table stand. She leans over and gives Garnet a kiss on the forehead before walking out. INT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ - FRONT ROOM — CONTINUOUS Al4 Theoliver, coat off and tie loose, dozes off in a deep cushioned chair next to a radio in the corner. Richard sits at the dining table under a bare bulb. He’s hunched over a sheet of drafting paper. He moves a pencil around a slide rule sketching plans for their house. Mildred enters and stops to look over his work. She place her hands on his shoulders and leans down to him.  15 16 17 11.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m turning in.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What you think about our bedroom in the back?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I'll love it however you make it. She moves away and he grabs her hand, pulling her back in a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I'll be in there soon.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Okay. Mildred exits to the bedroom. Richard returns to his plan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bricks laid, mortar spread. It’s a routine at the bustlin job site. Richard moves with the bricks. He barely pauses to run hi sleeve across his brow in the summer heat. INT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE/BEDROOM - DAY 16 Mildred runs fabric through a foot pedal sewing machine. She examines the stitch. Pleased, she carries the blanket over to Garnet who is preparing a basket as a bassinet. Mildred’s hand moves to her stomach, wincing at a kick. Garnet reaches out to feel for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard stands at the back of the store scanning a pegboa of automotive belts. He already cradles an assortment of other items.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FRONT OF THE STORE,
dialogues.text: A few CUSTOMERS mingle around. Mildred stands near the do flipping through a box of packets containing clothing patterns. She is being watched by the CASHIER(52), an old black woman smoking a long cigarette.  18 19 12. The Cashier watches Mildred’s fingers flipping through th packets. She sees the ring. Richard approaches Mildred with his items. He stands clos behind her. Mildred removes a pattern to show him.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I thought like this? He nods in agreement and places his hand on the small of back. At this, the Cashier’s mouth furrows. Richard breaks away and walks toward the Cashier. He sets his items on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hey Clara. That frame come in for me?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: It’s in the back. The Cashier climbs off her stool and shuffles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Raymond work under the body of the race car illuminated by a metal flood lamp. Mildred, in silhouette, leans against a table watching th EXT. LOLA’S HOUSE - DAY 19 Lola dumps a tin of water off the front porch as Richard' car pulls up and parks. He climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hey Momma. Richard walks toward the barn in back.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Sheriff's Deputy came by lookin’ for you. This stops him. He turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What’d he want?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Wanted to find you.  20 21 13.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You tell him where I was?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I didn’t have nothin’ to tell him. Lola begins scrubbing the tin down. Richard processes this news, unsettled by it. He continue on to the barn. INT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE/BEDROOM - DAY 20 A blank plaster wall. The back of Richard’s head raises up. He hammers at the w for a moment before bending back down leaving a nail in place. He stands back up now holding a large picture frame. He places it on the wall, making sure it’s straight before walking out of the bedroom. Richard and Mildred’s marriage certificate is left hangin there. INT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE - NIGHT 21 Bowls of food are passed for supper at Mildred’s house. H parents, Garnet, Richard, and two cousins, GERALD(27) and DAVIS(22), are all there around the table. It’s a nice meal and everyone seems at ease.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: What you like Rich? Ford or Chevy?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Not much difference.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: But which one faster?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That just depend on who built it.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: That’s what I said.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: How much money you win with that car?  22 23 24 25 14.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: Boy why you askin’ him ‘bout his money?

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: He don’t have to answer me. (back to Richard) How many races you won? Richard looks up from his plate for the first time. He ta time to calculate on his fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: A lot. This makes Mildred laugh. EXT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE - NIGHT 22 It’s late. The farmhouse is dark and the surrounding countryside is even darker. The night is hot and still. INT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE - CONTINUOUS 23 The front room is dark. The icebox hums in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bedroom, Richard and Mildred sleep soundly. EXT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE - CONTINUOUS 25

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DIRT DRIVE LEADING UP TO THE HOUSE,
dialogues.text: Two police cars are parked off to the side under the tree No headlights. No engines running. After a moment, the doors open and THREE MEN quietly step out. Two from the first car and one from the second. They walk toward the house in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PORCH,
dialogues.text: A hand reaches for the front door. It turns the knob. The unlocked door falls open.  26 15. The Men enter. INT. MILDRED’S PARENTS’ FARMHOUSE/BEDROOM - NIGHT 26 Richard and Mildred sleep undisturbed. Still no sounds in the house. Until...

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: The bedroom door is kicked open as blinding flashlights p on.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF BROOKS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In here! The Three Men rush inside. Richard sits up, a hand out to shield his squinting eyes. SHERIFF BROOKS (CONT’D) What you doin’ in that bed boy? Richard is yanked out of the bed wearing only boxers and undershirt. Off balance, he’s slung to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Richard?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF BROOKS
dialogues.text: (to Mildred) Get outta that bed. Mildred, wearing a nightgown, slowly climbs out of the be SHERIFF BROOKS (CONT’D) (over Richard) What’re you doin’ in bed with that woman?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I'm his wife. Richard points to the wall leading SHERIFF BROOK’s flashl up to the framed marriage certificate.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF BROOKS
dialogues.text: That’s no good here. Get your pants on boy. The other two men, a DEPUTY and the COUNTY JAILER, pick Richard up by the arms as he scrambles to put on the work pants he’d left over a chair.  27 28 16. Mildred’s father appears in the doorway as Sheriff Brooks leads her out of the bedroom in her nightgown. Theoliver steps out of the way, saying nothing as Richard led out behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two police cars are parked in a dirt lot behind the r bricked county jail. Richard and Mildred, both in handcuffs, have been carried separate vehicles. They are removed from their respective backseats by the Deputy and Jailer. Sheriff Brooks, with no comment, walks off toward an adja parking lot as the prisoners are led around front. A bare bulb mounted above the barred door is all that lig the dark, two story structure. Bars cover the windows on second floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jail is dark and dank. The large metal front door opens directly onto a flight o concrete steps that lead up to the cells. The barred wind offer no protection from the elements. Metal creaks as Richard is the first to enter and be led upstairs. Mildred is close behind. A tiny, single cell waits at the top. The Jailer holding Richard addresses the Deputy.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: She goes in there. Richard is turned and taken further inside toward a large communal cell down the hall. Richard strains to turn back He’s able to catch Mildred’s eye.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Mildred, still in her slippers and nightgown, looks terrified. The Deputy unlocks the door to her cell. Richard tries to keep an eye on her as the Jailer removes handcuffs and unlocks the communal cell.  29 30 17. Richard is pushed inside.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COMMUNAL CELL,
dialogues.text: Richard immediately turns back to the bars being slammed his face. He tries to see down the hall to Mildred but can’t. He steps back, his eyes darting around trying to find an answer that isn’t coming. He brings his hand up to his fa to cover his hurried breathing. Stuck, he begins to gather himself. He turns to the large open cell. Shadowy FIGURES line the walls and pace around the windows. Mostly drunks, one mumbles in the corner. Richard backs into an open spot on the wall by the door. leans there, keeping his eyes on the room.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SINGLE CELL,
dialogues.text: Mildred is balled up in the corner. The cell is barely bi enough to contain the filthy cot she’s huddled on. She's trembling, trying to control her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, the town of Bowling Green is quiet. The jail sits just a few yards away from the county courthouse. A statue of a confederate soldier stands betw the two buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight streams through the bars of the communal cell. Richard hasn’t moved from his spot on the wall. Several other MEN, black and white, are sprawled out across the c The sound of traffic bustles from the town outside. Richard barely moves his head at the sound of the big met door downstairs opening. Footsteps climb the steps in no kind of hurry. Keys jingle and the cell door opens.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: Richard Loving?  18.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Here. Richard straightens, stiff from the long night, and moves the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: You made bail. Richard quickly steps out of the cell and moves down the looking for Mildred. He sees her still huddled on the cot in her cell.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Bean? Mildred lifts her head to find Richard approaching. She immediately gets to her feet and goes to the cell door.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Richard? As Richard approaches her, the Jailer grabs him by the shoulder to steer him downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: On down. Richard resists.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What about her?

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: Just you.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Richard? The Jailer moves Richard further down the stairs. Richard tries to pull back.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Wait. The Jailer yanks his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: Don’t pull me again.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That’s not right.  31 32 33 19. The Jailer moves him on downstairs. Richard turns to see Mildred. She stands at the bars watching him go.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's not right now! At the bottom of the steps he loses sight of her. The Jai shoves him outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard stumbles out the door into bright sunlight. He covers his eyes as the metal door slams shut. The Jailer keeps a hold of him and leads him across the l toward the courthouse. Richard looks over to the small Sheriff's office that sit a building behind the jail. Sheriff Brooks stands outside sipping a cup of coffee. He watches Richard. Richard averts his eyes. INT. CAROLINE COUNTY COURTHOUSE/CLERK’S OFFICE - DAY 32 Richard stands in front of a desk in the CLERK’s office collecting his wallet and keys.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Sign at the bottom. The Clerk, a white man in his early 60's, presents a pape and pen to him. Richard bends over to sign.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What about my wife?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You'll have to talk to the Judge about that on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Monday? Richard waits for a response, but the Clerk just hands hi receipt for his things. Richard walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard walks outside to find Raymond waiting for him by car on the street.  34 35 20. They don’t speak. They just climb in the car and Raymond drives away. INT. LOLA’S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 34 A scream. The pregnant young White Girl sits in a bed in the center the front room in the midst of labor. Her HUSBAND(25) sta by looking pale. Lola performs her midwife duties in the middle of it all.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Richard! Richard enters from the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bring me that fresh water and take this one out. Richard moves to the wood stove and a uses a towel to gra the fresh bucket of water. He replaces it with one at Lol feet and heads back out to the front porch. EXT. LOLA’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 35 Richard walks onto the porch and dumps the bucket off to side of the house. Setting the bucket down, he joins Raymond on the railing looking out over the small community of houses. SEVERAL PEOPLE mill about.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK BEAZELY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We'll walk over there in a minute, but I met with the Judge this morning and I was able to work out a deal that I think is fair. FRANK BEAZELY(58) is a polished small town lawyer. FRANK BEAZELY (CONT’D) Judge Bazile is a friend, but he is not a fan of your particular situation. If you all plead guilty, the judge is willing to suspend any prison time. dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK BEAZELY
dialogues.text: Now in exchange for suspending the jail time, you and your wife, unless of course you choose to dissolve the marriage, will be forced to leave the state.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Leave the state? What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK BEAZELY
dialogues.text: It’s exactly what it sounds like. You will not be allowed to remain in the state together. dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: For how long? How long will that last? Frank chews on his cheek, reluctant to give the details.

dialogues.text: ...the said Richard Perry Loving, being a white person and the said Mildred Dolores Jeter being a colored person, did unlawfully and feloniously go out of the state of Virginia, for the purpose of being married in the District of Columbia on June 2nd, 1958, and afterwards returned to and resided in the County of Caroline, State of Virginia, cohabitating as man and wife against the peace and dignity of the Commonwealth. dialogues.text: Thank you Momma. Lola pauses in a rare moment of introspection.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: You never shoulda married that girl. Richard doesn’t even turn to answer this.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I thought you liked her.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I like a lot of people. That doesn’t mean you shoulda gone and done what you did. You knew better. Richard doesn’t engage. He takes a pull from his cigarett and goes back to watching the street. Lola walks inside. INT. LOLA’S HOUSE - DAY 80 A new baby’s face swaddled tight.  81 82 42.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sidney. Sidney. Garnet holds him, speaking gently. Mildred and Richard sit on the couch watching. Mildred is dressed and looking somewhat recovered. Mildred’s mother is also there. They all study the child. Garnet stands and hands the baby back to Mildred. The SOUND of cars pulling up. The two men walk forward and stop by the hoods of their c They wait there. Richard turns to Mildred.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Call Frank Beazely. Richard walks outside. Mildred doesn’t move from the couc EXT. LOLA’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 81 Richard steps onto the front porch. His eyes meet the Sheriff's. dialogues.text: Tell that woman to come out here.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: She’s not here.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF BROOKS
dialogues.text: Boy. I will split your head to the white meat and then go arrest every soul in that house. I won’t ask again. INT. LOLA’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 82 Mildred kisses the baby on the forehead and hands him ove Garnet.  83 84 85 43.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Mildred find themselves standing once again a the table in front of Judge Bazile’s bench. The Judge studies a transcript and looks lowly at them ov the bridge of his glasses.

dialogues.text: For violation of your parole, you are ordered to post a two-hundred- dollar bond and are to appear in front of this court on... The Judge looks to the COURT SECRETARY for his answer. This foils the Judge’s response. He re-calibrates for a moment, pretending to study a paper in front of him. FRANK BEAZELY (CONT’D) Your Honor... Judge Bazile holds up a hand.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE BAZILE

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN,
dialogues.text: 93 46. Mildred spoons applesauce to PEGGY, a baby, sitting in a chair wearing a pink dress. The doorbell RINGS. Mildred quickly wipes at Peggy’s face and scoops her out the high chair.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FRONT ROOM,
dialogues.text: Mildred rushes to the front door and calls upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Sidney! Don! Come on down! She opens the door to find Garnet standing there. Mildred throws herself at her sister. Hugging her fiercel Garnet smiles at this, but the hug is severe. Mildred pulls back and Garnet sees the tears in her eyes. Mildred takes her by the hand and drags her inside. INT. COUSIN’S ROW HOUSE IN D.C. - LATER 93 Garnet sits on the couch holding Peggy. Mildred sits clos to her. Donald and Sidney run up, then down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: ..-and Sue and Terry send their love. They just had a little girl too.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: Their second.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Oh. A BOOM as Sidney jumps from a high stair and hits the flo He dares Donald.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: You go.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Sidney, don’t jump in the house. The boys disappear back up the stairs. Garnet smiles as s watches them go.  94 95 47.

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: They're big.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yes. I hate it for ‘em. It’s like they’re caged. Not even any grass to run in. Garnet can’t think of a response.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: He’s fine. He stays up in that chair more than in the field. I told Momma if he don’t start getting some work done Mr. Banks liable to find someone else for it. Clay said he’d have to... As Garnet continues, Mildred watches her but can’t help feeling distant even with her there. EXT. Garnet honks the horn and throws a wave from the window a she drives away. Mildred watches her go. INT. dialogues.text: How was your sister?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: She’s fine. Mildred doesn’t turn, doesn’t engage. Richard picks up on it. He watches her slowly scrubbing at the dishes.  48. 96 INT. dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You boys stop that wrestlin’! Come help Miss Laura with these groceries!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: They say over a hundred thousand people are there. Laura moves into the kitchen. From there,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you imagine? Mildred speaks low, to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Might as well be half way ‘round the world.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Nothing. Laura walks back in holding items from her grocery bags.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You know what you need to do?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.text: You need to write Bobby Kennedy. Mildred laughs this off.  97 98 99

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m serious. That’s what he’s up there for. Laura goes back into the kitchen, continuing her thought.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All this talk of civil rights. You need to get you some civil rights. Mildred shakes her head at this. She watches the images. She notices Peggy’s face, engrossed by the TV. COUSIN’S ROW HOUSE IN D.C. - NIGHT 99 Richard enters the dark house carrying his items from wor His clothes are dusty from a day’s labor. He walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.text: Richard takes a seat at the table. He sets his lunch pail and tool bag down. He’s beat.  100 50. Mildred enters. Without a word, she goes to the sink to g him a glass of water.

dialogues.text: Yes. She places the glass in front of him and moves behind him She rubs at his shoulders. He relaxes at this.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Byrd residence.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through the phone) Hello, I’m calling to speak to a Mildred Loving.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: This is she.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello Mrs. Loving, my name is Bernard Cohen, I’m a lawyer that was referred to you by the ACLU. Are you familiar?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. No.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You wrote a letter to Attorney General Kennedy, is that right? Mildred hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He was not able to help with your particular case and sent your letter on to the American Civil Liberties Union. The ACLU contacted me, I’m a lawyer in Virginia, and we would like to help you with your case.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I see. Donald runs into the room with the toy. Peggy is in hot pursuit.  52.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Momma ! Momma! Mildred covers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Baby hush. Don. The children are out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would it be possible for you and your husband to meet with me?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I would have to check with my husband.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m based in Alexandria, but I have an office in D.c. if that is a concern.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Well, as I said in my letter, we really can’t afford a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No ma’am. The ACLU would take care of any fees. Mildred nearly drops the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Wonderful. I’11 have my secretary call you back to set up a time. Nice speaking to you Mrs. Loving. dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I got a call from a lawyer today.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yes, from the American Civil Liberties Union. Robert Kennedy told him to call us. Richard continues undressing, not taking it in. Mildred finishes the shirt and hands it to Donald.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go help your sister brush her teeth. Donald exits as he pulls the mended shirt over his head.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They'd like to help with our case.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We can’t afford a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: They said they wouldn’t charge us. This stops Richard. He’s paying attention now, but lookin skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to see him on Thursday. His name is Cohen. Richard gives a faint nod. Mildred smiles and exits to th children’s room. Richard processes what may have been an ambush.

dialogues.text: Polished shoes tap along a linoleum hallway. BERNIE COHEN(29) is a dapper man in a suit and hat. He carries a briefcase and walks with a confident stride. He enters a glass door.  104 105 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECRETARY sits at a desk just inside the law office.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Bernard Cohen. I’m in from Richmond. I talked to Jack about using his office for a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes Mr. Cohen, do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Third door?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes. Bernie walks to a connecting hall but turns back on his w

dialogues.text: My clients are Mr. and Mrs. Loving. Could you send them down when they arrive?

dialogues.text: Certainly. Bernie finds the third door. There is a name plate there reading “JACK GREEN.” Cohen slips the plate out of its holder and places it in jacket pocket. dialogues.text: The office is tidy and nicely furnished. Bernie immediately goes to the desk and begins gathering collection of frames containing pictures of the other lawyer's family. He goes behind the desk and places the frames in the top drawer. He lays out a pad and pen from his briefcase. There is a KNOCK at the door. Cohen takes a seat in the desk chair and readies himself.  55.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens and Mildred enters, followed by Richard. Bernie immediately stands and comes around to offer his h

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Loving?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: So nice to meet you. Please, have a seat. He turns to Richard and they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bernard Cohen. It’s a pleasure. Richard sits, staying quiet. Bernie takes note of his demeanor as he goes back behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming in today. So as we discussed on the phone, the ACLU would like to take on your case. I was actually a charter member of the ACLU here in Virginia which is why they assigned me to you. The bottom line is, we want to get you all some relief.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: That’s very generous. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: I took the liberty of contacting the courthouse in Bowling Green and have started a file for you. Now the first step is to appeal the sentence in Caroline County. That will be our fastest route into Federal Court. The problem is...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Federal court?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Yes, the goal is to try and get the Federal Court to hear this case so we can get...  56.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: ‘Scuse me, but I don’t understand Federal Court.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Well I see it as the best route...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Can’t you just go talk to Judge Bazile? I mean we aren’t hurtin’ anybody. Can’t you just go tell him that?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: I don’t think...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Just talk to him. Tell him if he lets us back in the state we won’t bother anybody. Bernie takes a moment, recalculating his approach.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Look, I do not think this is going to be resolved in Judge Bazile’s court, or probably any other court in the state of Virginia for that matter. I believe this is a court battle that could possibly go all the way to the highest court in the land. Richard looks at him blankly. Bernie gets specific.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: We're listening. Seeing an ally in Mildred, he starts back in with his foc toward her.  57.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Our problem is that in order to appeal the judgment of conviction, we would’ve needed to do so within 60 days. Now given that it’s been five years since that conviction, we have to find a way to get this case back into the courts. Are you following? Mildred nods with a pleasant smile. Richard gives a nod.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve given this some thought and I have a somewhat unorthodox idea on how to do this, but in order to get this back into the stream of the courts, given that you are currently on probation, my suggestion would be for the two of you to return to Caroline County, get re-arrested, and then we will have an avenue for our appeal. Richard looks at him as if his face is on upside down.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You want us to get arrested again?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s an idea. I of course would be there to bail you out. Richard looks to Mildred. She catches his eyes, but then looks down. She tries to keep her smile.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We aren’t gonna do that. Bernie chews on this, realizing his misstep.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Right. That’s not...I can see how that was a bad idea. I understand. Look, I need to do some more thinking on this first issue, but again, bottom line, we’re gonna get you all some help. Mildred smiles at him and stands. She reaches her hand ou across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: We appreciate you. We really do.  106 107 108 109 58. Richard stands and shakes Bernie’s hand but is quickly ou the door. Mildred follows. The door shuts and Bernie is left alone. He leans back in the chair and let’s out a breath. He tos his pen down, displeased with his performance.

NEIGHBORHOOD - MOVING - DAY 107 The two ride in silence. Mildred stares out at the city.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: If it gets us home, we’ll take their help.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Well. You get what you pay for. Mildred keeps her eyes out the window.

dialogues.text: Don!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Mildred!

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Up here! Richard bounds up the stairs. He sees a light on in the children’s room and heads for i INT.
