Sidney holds Peggy on an opposite bed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What’s goin’ on?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Donald got hit by a car today. Richard goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s fine. Just scraped and bruised is all. Richard is immediately relieved but stays perched on the next to him. He runs his hand gently over the boy’s chest Mildred stands and exits the room. Richard watches her go, trying to put things together. He turns back to Donald.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You okay? Donald nods sullenly. INT. COUSIN’S ROW HOUSE IN D.C. - NIGHT 118 Richard reaches the bottom of the stairs in the front roo find Mildred sitting rigid on the couch.  62.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: We're moving back to the country. I don’t care what they do to us. I won't raise my family here. Richard looks at the luggage and boxes. He stands there f awhile. Both are silent. Richard finally walks over and sits next to her on the co He places his arm around her. Her face finally breaks. She leans into him. EXT. COUSIN’S ROW HOUSE IN D.C. - DAY 119 Mildred’s car is loaded with bags and boxes. Sidney and Donald laugh playing grab ass on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ya’ll get loaded up now. Richard leaves the car door open and walks over to Laura Alex at the bottom of the stoop. Mildred is there with Peggy. Richard shakes Alex’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks Al.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: All right. He hugs Laura, then grabs Peggy and steps back toward the to herd the kids.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Come on now. Mildred hugs Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just go on. Mildred exchanges a smile with her.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Thank you. Laura and Alex walk back inside as Mildred turns to the c Richard has the kids loaded. Mildred gets behind the whee  120 121 63.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I‘1l see you tonight. Richard kisses her through the open driver’s window. He r on the roof and eyes the children in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ya’ll be good. Mildred pulls the car away. Richard takes keys out of his pocket and crosses the stre to his own car, which is also packed with boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three-story Victorian-style boarding house stands secluded in the middle of farmland. The sun has recently and a blue hue hangs over everything.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WRAP AROUND PORCH,
dialogues.text: A young black BOY(9) sits in a rocking chair next to his GRANDMOTHER(72). They are enjoying the night air. Headlights appear and lead Richard’s car down the dirt dr The Boy watches as Richard’s car pulls around to the back the house to park. The Boy gets up and walks to the edge of the porch. He sees Richard climb out of his car, one of many parked the back lot. Richard carries his tools toward a back doo The Boy runs inside through the front entrance to the hou

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MAIN SITTING ROOM,
dialogues.text: The Boy stands unseen in the front room. He spies on Rich walking in the back door near the kitchen. Richard disappears up a back set of stairs. The Boy rushes up the main stairs.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS,
dialogues.text: A long hallway shows several numbered doors.  122 123 64. The Boy reaches the top of the stairs in time to spy Rich standing at a door at the end of the hallway. Richard knocks lightly and checks over his shoulder. He doesn’t see the Boy. The door opens and the Boy sees Mildred there. Richard slips in. Through the sliver, the Boy makes out Donald and Sidney jumping on the bed behind Mildred. The door closes. With the show over, the Boy disappears b downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, Donald and Peggy run alongside the field that bor the house. The Boy from the porch runs with them. They laugh, playing tag and dodging in and out of the cro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard pulls back a curtain to see outside. He spots the children playing. Mildred sits on the bed and Raymond stands against the do

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: My cousin has a house he might rent out.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I thought Jim’s brother said it was fine here.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t trust it. Too many people. (to Raymond) Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: King and Queen County. Just a farmhouse up there. I figure it gets you out of the county but keeps you close. You’ll be on your own out there. It don’t have no phone or nothin’. But no one’s gonna find you less they know to look. I can get word to you when you need it.  124 125 65.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How much you think he’d want for it?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: He'll be fair. Richard nods. He hasn't taken his eyes off the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red-winged black birds glide over a rolling hillside plan with corn. Mildred steers the car up a gravel path with Peggy and Do beside her. She studies the tree canopies that line the drive and then slows the car to a stop. Mildred takes in the house up ahead. It’s perfect. A white farmhouse with a wide porch. There are multiple o buildings and a massive oak tree in the yard. Grass everywhere leads to rolling farmland. A horn honks behind her, snapping her out of the gaze. Richard is with Sidney in the car behind them. Mildred pu ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred has parked near the house. She steps out of the c The children burst off the front seat and sprint for the house. They start running circles around it. Richard parks nearby. Sidney jumps out and joins his siblings. Richard begins untying the luggage on the roof. Mildred meanwhile slips off her shoes. She puts her feet the grass. Closing her eyes, she takes a breath and curls her toes. Richard watches her, happy to see her there. He takes in property. It’s a nice spot with a high vantage point. You can see who might be coming in multiple directions. Richard goes back to the luggage.  126 127 128 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, dressed for work, enters the kitchen to kiss Mil goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’ll try and get home ‘fore dark.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: We'll be fine. Richard is out the door. Mildred sits at the kitchen table as a pot of something steams on the stove. She is in the middle of writing another letter. A portion of it reads: “,..We haven’t heard anything from you for so long we had given up hope.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie sits behind his desk reading Mildred’s latest lett He mouths a collection of the words. Bernie puts the letter down, frustrated. He thinks for a moment and then presses the intercom button on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Martha, I need you to call Chet Antieau’s office at Georgetown and try to set a meeting. INT. GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY/ANTIEAU’S OFFICE - DAY 128 A SECRETARY knocks at an office door.

dialogues.speaker: CHET ANTIEAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come in. The Secretary enters and finds CHET ANTIEAU(51) sitting i high backed chair talking with PHIL HIRSCHKOP(27), a baby faced man with dark hair wearing a neat blue suit.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: I'd never seen anything like it. No matter how many times I go down there I find something that surprises me.  67.

dialogues.speaker: ANTIEAU'S SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. The Secretary sets a note down in front of Chet who gives a glance.

dialogues.speaker: CHET ANTIEAU
dialogues.text: Oh yes, please bring him back. The Secretary exits. CHET ANTIEAU (CONT’D) This is good timing. I want you to meet a former student of mine. He called about a case you may find interesting.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: Sure, what’s it about? At that moment, Bernie Cohen is shown into the room. He enters with a smile and a hand extended to Chet.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Hello Professor, thanks for seeing me. Chet stands to shake.

dialogues.speaker: CHET ANTIEAU
dialogues.text: My pleasure. You came at a good time Bernie. This is Phil Hirschkop, he’s a brilliant civil rights lawyer. Phil scoffs at this. CHET ANTIEAU (CONT’D) Is it all right if he joins us?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Please. It’s nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) You too. Bernie takes a seat in the open chair.

dialogues.speaker: CHET ANTIEAU
dialogues.text: So what’s the problem?  129 68.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Well, I’m a bit stumped. The ACLU referred this case to me concerning an interracial couple that was married in D.C. They were arrested for living together in Virginia and the judge suspended their prison sentence under order that they leave the state for 25 years. I filed a motion to vacate the judgement with Judge Bazile, the original trial judge in Caroline County, but he’s stonewalling me. He’s had my motion under advisement for months, and I feel like he could keep it that way until he retires. Of course the ACLU sees this, and I agree, as a potential contender to repeal anti- miscegenation laws nationwide. I just need to get the ball rolling as it were. Chet looks over to Phil, whose eyebrows are raised.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: That’s a remarkable case.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: I’m stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie and Phil walk through the campus continuing what h been a very long conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: But that may not solve the issue.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: It’s a very delicate situation because by appealing you open up the possibility of sending both of them to prison. I think regardless you file the 1983 motion explaining your complaint. It’1ll force Bazile’s hand and get you in front of a federal three-judge panel. Phil checks his watch.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I’m catching a plane to New York tonight. I’11 work up a draft on the plane and find you Monday.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: That's great. That’s just great. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: Bernie, if you don’t mind me asking, how much experience do you have with constitutional law?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Some. Bernie takes a moment, then amends.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very little.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: You realize this case could alter the constitution of the United States?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: I do. Phil smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: I’11 call you on Monday. Phil walks away. Bernie takes a deep breath, left alone w the ivy under the tower of Healy Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola helps Mildred roll out dough in the kitchen. Both we aprons and have flour up to their elbows.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I never can get mine to rise.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: It’s not you. It’s the humidity. Just thick. Peggy, now four, runs in and tugs on her Grandmother.  131 70.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Come look Meme. Come look.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: She’s fine. Lola lets herself get taken outside.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you want from your Meme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard stands on a ladder hammering together a wooden fr against the doorway of one of the out buildings. It will hold a winch to lift the motor that sits rusting nearby. Peggy drags Lola onto the porch to see a makeshift play t set for tea with a collection of dolls. She picks one up.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Lilly won't share her tea.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: She must be upset. Richard, from the vantage point of the ladder, sees Raymo car tearing toward the house. Dust flying. Richard watches, but a panic slowly takes over. He slides off the ladder and runs toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Bean! Call the boys! Peggy take Meme inside. Richard runs down the drive toward Raymond's car. The car slides to a stop in a cloud of dust. Raymond clim out, in no real hurry. Richard arrives out of breath. His hands hit his knees.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I got a message for you.  132 71.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: That lawyer called. Says he needs to meet with ya’ll. Richard stands straight. He looks back at the house to he Mildred calling for the boys from the porch. His attentio goes back to his friend.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Raymond, why you driving so fast like that?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What you mean? That’s how I always drive. Richard shakes his head, slowly coming around. He snorts a laugh and walks back toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie sits behind the desk in his office as Phil, in a c on his left, reads from a file.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: (reading) Almighty God created the races white, black, yellow, malay, and red, and he placed them on separate continents. Mildred and Richard listen from wing chairs facing them. Richard is slouched in dirty work clothes.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-And but for the interference with his arrangement there would be no cause for such marriages. The fact that he separated the races shows that he did not intend for the races to mix. Phil looks up from the paper and smiles at the Lovings.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it sounds strange, but this is really wonderful.  72. Richard squirms in his seat, not convinced.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By issuing this ruling, Judge Bazile has really given us a road map to the Supreme Court.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m confused. He ruled against us, again.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: That's right, but now we’re allowed to appeal this ruling to the state. From there, if they rule against you, we'll have a chance at the Supreme Court. Richard just stays quiet. Mildred nods politely.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: That sounds wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Now, a little bit of housekeeping, LIFE Magazine contacted us about sending a photographer out to you all. Keeping the possibility of the Supreme Court in mind, I think it’s a fair idea to raise the profile of your case, but I of course want you all to be comfortable with it. Mildred looks over to Richard, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: That will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Okay, great. We’ll set that up. Mildred raises out of her seat and shakes Phil’s hand. Richard follows her lead.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Thank you for everything. Bernie stands and escorts them to the door. They exit. Bernie closes the door behind them. He turns and looks at Phil who is still in his chair.  133 73.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: You know Bernie, I’ve spent a lot of time down South, between the marches and working with Kunstler, and one thing I can tell you, that guy looks like a redneck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard strains against the chain that lifts the rusted m through the winch. It hangs precariously above a cavity i an empty car’s hood. Richard locks off the chain with a hook on the side of th outbuilding and goes to start pushing the car away. Something catches his eye. He raises up. A MAN APPROACHES ON FOOT UP THE DRIVE. Richard walks over and makes himself known. The man is tall, standing 6'4”. He wears a lean suit, carries a suitcase, and has a camera dangling from his ne This is GREY VILLET(39). Grey holds a hand up to wave as he approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: Hello. Richard stands his ground. Grey approaches and holds out hand. Richard takes it tentatively. GREY VILLET (CONT’D) Grey Villet. LIFE Magazine. What you got there, a V8? Grey doesn’t seem the least bit flustered by Richard givi him a wary eye. He makes his way over to the dangling engine. GREY VILLET (CONT’D) What’s the trouble? Richard allows himself to be drawn in.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Camshaft.

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: Then you're a better mechanic than me.  134 74. Grey walks toward the house, not stopping to speak. GREY VILLET (CONT’D) Of course all that rust on the crankshaft would be your second chore. Your wife inside? As Grey walks up to the house, Mildred steps out onto the porch. Grey continues approaching with a wave. GREY VILLET (CONT’D) Mrs. Loving, Grey Villet, LIFE Magazine. Something smells good in there. May I? Grey wipes his feet and disappears inside. Mildred follow Richard is left by the rusty motor. He smiles at the oddi of this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. The family sits around the dinner table hanging on one of Grey’s stories.

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: «-+-I couldn’t go back with no photo. No photo, no job, and this is LIFE Magazine and the pigeon guy wasn’t around.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: (laughing) Pigeon guy.

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: So I look up at this office building and it hits me. I go 55 stories up and talk some office girls to let me by the window. Before they could do anything, I threw open the window and dangled my feet out. They start screaming, but I got this great shot of my feet flying over 42nd and 5th Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: Security threw me out head first.  135 136 75. This makes Richard laugh. GREY VILLET (CONT’D) LIFE hired me the next day. Richard finishes off his plate.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That’s a story all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred stands at the sink cleaning up the dishes. Grey stands next to her holding his camera. Behind them in the den, Richard crosses from the couch to join the kids upstairs, who can be heard playing.

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: So you go to the Virginia State Court tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: You nervous?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I suppose. The lawyers told us not to expect much.

dialogues.speaker: GREY VILLET
dialogues.text: You think you’1l lose?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Well, yes. But I think it’s all right. We may lose the small battles but win the big war. Grey smiles at her. He snaps a photo, making her blush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey sits on the floor with his back against the wall. A cigarette dangles from his lips as he polishes the face o his watch. His camera sits next to him. The kids are in bed. Mildred and Richard sit on the couch next to each other watching the Andy Griffith show on TV. They laugh at the episode.  137 76. Grey watches as Richard makes himself more comfortable. H stretches out on the couch, placing his head on Mildred’s lap. It’s a delicate pose. A happy one. Grey quietly reaches for his camera and snaps a quick sho from his chest. He gently sets the camera back down and goes back to polishing the watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Mildred walk hand and hand out of the massive Virginia Supreme Court Building in Richmond. Mildred wears a long coat and Richard is dressed in a thr button suit and tie. REPORTERS, armed with film and still cameras, track them the sidewalk. Richard walks stiff as a board.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: Mr. Loving? Richard and Mildred turn at the sound of Phil’s voice. Phil is standing by one of the many film crews and waves back toward him. Richard and Mildred walk back.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They just want to ask you a few questions. A NEWS ANCHOR with a large microphone approaches and spea to Mildred first.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Loving... He pauses to address his CAMERA MAN.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You rolling? (to Mildred) Mrs. Loving, the Virginia Supreme Court just ruled against you, how do you feel about what happened here today?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Well, I feel hopeful. I’m hopeful.  77.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: Where are you going now?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I guess we'll go back to Washington.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: You'll go back to Washington. Mr. Loving, do you have anything to say about what went on in the court today?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No I don’t have anything to say.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: Okay. Mildred nods to the Reporter and Richard has already turn to leave. She keeps hold of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, cut Tommy. Richard and Mildred try to walk toward their car. Phil wa close behind them. Bernie is giving an interview to a different CAMERA CREW he sees them pass by.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Mr. And Mrs. Loving? Bernie walks over to them with the Camera Crew in tow. Ph takes a position next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted you all to know, with this travel back and forth to Virginia, you all have my number and if anybody arrests you, just have them get in touch with us and we’1ll hop right to it. We won’t let you stay in jail one minute longer than it takes us to get down there and get you out, okay?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: All right. Good luck to you.  138 139 78. Richard reaches out to shake both Bernie and Phil’s hands

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: You did a good job today. Richard, painfully shy in front of the cameras, sheepishl smiles. Mildred gives a polite laugh.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Well thank you, I sure appreciate what ya’ll’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Okay. See you. Richard and Mildred walk to their car. Richard checks ove his shoulder, rattled by the whole affair. The Camera Crew has backed off and is packing up their equipment. Phil and Bernie wave as the Loving’s car pulls away. Phil leans in to Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: You know there’s no guarantee that we can get them out if they get arrested again? Bernie watches the news media wrapping up. Showing unease now that the cameras are off, he nods to Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard works at a big job site out in the country. The 20 man CREW is constructing a power station. Richard, along with a few others, sets brick for a substation. The routine is there. Brick and mortar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard has wrapped up his work for the day and walks ove his car. It’s one of many parked nearby. Other Crew mingle about in the lot. Richard throws his tools into the backseat and reaches fo the driver’s door. He pauses.  140 141 79. Richard checks over his shoulder to see if anyone is watc him. Though seeing other workers, no one is looking at hi Richard opens the door and leans in. He picks up a BRICK that has been placed on the driver's seat. It is wrapped in the spread from LIFE Magazine complete with Grey Villet’s photos. Richard tears off the magazine pages and crams them in hi pocket. He drops the brick to the ground and climbs in. I/E. RICHARD’S CAR/BACK ROAD - MOVING - AFTERNOON 140 Richard drives through the back country on a rural road. continually checks the rearview. A TRUCK appears behind him. Richard studies it, not changing his speed. The truck han back at a distance. Richard comes to a turn and takes it sharply. Again, he maintains his speed, studying the rearview. The truck turns in behind him. Still at a distance. Richard pushes down on the pedal and speeds up. The truck follows suit. Richard’s speedometer climbs higher and higher. He eyes the rearview and sees the truck has maintained it distance. Richard is nervous. He approaches a curve. Once around, Richard floors the car. The engine chugs as he flies down the back road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has almost disappeared behind the fields that surround the farmhouse. Richard’s car flies down the gravel drive and skids to a near the house. He jumps out and rushes to the porch.  142 80.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Sidney! Richard watches the drive to see if anyone appears. Sidney, now eight years old, walks out of the house. He immediately can see his dad is on edge. Richard takes him by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Run over to the neighbors house and ask to use their phone. Call Raymond. Tell him to get over here and bring his gun. Go through the field. Sidney runs off without questioning. Mildred pokes her head out of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Just go on inside. Mildred looks concerned but can sense the tone in Richard voice. She returns inside. Richard goes back to staring at the distant tree lines th border their house. He watches, and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlights light up the side of the house as Raymond's ca rumbles up the drive. The lights wash over Richard, who hasn’t moved from his p on the porch. Richard steps down into the yard as Raymond climbs out of car. He reaches into the backseat and takes out a shotgun Raymond walks toward Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming.  143 144 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s late. Richard still stands guard on the porch. Raymond has taken a seat. He smokes a cigarette with the shotgun set across his lap.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: That truck may just been goin’ fishin’.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You ever hear from anyone at your work about it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Not to my face. Raymond studies his friend. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I'll say this Rich, nobody’s gonna tell you what you can’t do. Richard wishes he could smile at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy eats a Popsicle and stares at the TELEPHONE MAN installing a phone in their kitchen. The Man’s head is tucked near the wall finishing some wir He lifts the receiver off its base and finds a dial tone.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE MAN
dialogues.text: You're all set. Mildred moves from the stove, wiping her hands on an apro

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Thank you. She opens the back door for the Man to let him out.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Who we gonna call Mamma?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I don’t want you callin’ anybody.  145 146 147 82. Peggy stares at the phone finishing off her dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred steps outside in time to see the Telephone Man’s truck pulling away. Another car is parked in the yard. Garnet and their Mothe are climbing out of it. Garnet has to balance her weight as she is pregnant and showing.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: How'd that go?

dialogues.speaker: GARNET
dialogues.text: Doctor said she’ll be fine. Just put her on aspirin. Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Telephone man. Richard had them install a phone. Momma you feel okay?

dialogues.speaker: MUSIEL
dialogues.text: Yes. You have some tea I can drink?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Come on. Mildred shepherds her Mother inside as Garnet follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard parks his car near the house. He gets out with his tools and studies a van parked in th yard. He walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard enters the house and is surprised to see a TWO PE FILM CREW standing in their den. The INTERVIEWER, a young woman, holds a microphone. A YOU MAN holds the camera. They film Mildred on the couch as the children play aroun them.  148 149 83.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Mildred. Come here. Richard walks outside on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard paces on the porch. Mildred steps outside and he gets close. He speaks in a forced whisper.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t want those people here. I’m done with all these cameras. Richard steps back, waiting for Mildred to do something.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I think it’s important. These people want to help us. Mildred walks back into the house. Richard bites at his lip, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard walks back inside. Mildred is on the couch again being interviewed.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: ...it’s the principle. It’s the law. I don’t think it’s right. And if we do win we will be helping a lot of people. Richard walks over and takes a seat in a chair. Peggy wal up and leans against her father.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I know we have some enemies, but we have some friends too. So it really don’t make any difference about my enemies. Mildred gives a polite smile. Richard looks up and sees that the Young Man has pointed camera at him. He looks down, trying to avoid it all.  150 151 84. EXT. DRAG RACING PARK —- DAY 150 This strip is big. It’s a rally with cars lined up waitin for their turn on the track. People mingle around, drinking and watching cars race. Richard stands on the track at the rear of their car. Raymond is beside him. Their car idles next to another vehicle at the starting line. Percy stands near the front of the car watching Virgil be the wheel. A pole of lights cycle to green and the cars launch off t starting line. The race is over quickly, with Virgil barely pulling out win.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Car looks good.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It’s runnin’ all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small shack is filled with music and people dancing. Richard sits at a table with Percy, Raymond and Virgil. They're well into a bottle of liquor and not bothering wi setups.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: I miss you Rich. Hell I can say it. Percy, don’t you miss Rich? With a shrug,

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I miss you too Virgil.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: So what’s with all this?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: All a what?  85.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: What you got. You just made it too hard now. Richard fends this with a half smile and nod.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See you think I’m crazy but you know what hard is now don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Raymond keeps a watchful eye on Virgil.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: You white Richard. You think you like a black man but you white. You hang ‘round all these black folks but when you go to work you still white. But not now. Now you know what it’s like. You black now aren’t you? You a damn fool.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Come on now.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: He need to hear it. Every nigga up in here wish he were you Rich, and you ain’t got sense enough for it. But see you got the fix. I ain’t got no fix. Yourn easy. All you gotta do is divorce her. That’s easy. That’s all you gotta do.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Divorce her?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: That's right. Easy. Richard smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m gonna divorce her.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: That’s all you gotta do. Richard’s smile fades as he picks up the bottle and pours another round. He slams back the drink. Raymond stares down Virgil, who is oblivious.  152 153 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred lifts her head off the pillow when she hears Rich enter the room. He takes a seat on the end of the bed and removes his boo She can’t see his face. He sits there, quiet. Until finally mumbling, inaudible.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Come to bed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We been talking to lawyers near ten years now.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Let’s go to bed. Mildred tries to see his face but can’t. She moves to the end of the bed to sit next to him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I can take care of you. Mildred can see he’s drunk and speaks slightly dismissive

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know that. She puts her hand on his back. He finally looks at her. His eyes have tears in them. She has rarely seen him like this.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I can take care of you. Mildred begins to nod.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know. Richard looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, his heavy coat on, steps outside the front door.  154 155 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ground is covered in snow. The fields and trees are a white with ice. Richard crunches across the yard to a wood pile and begin gathering up a stack. A shiny black Lincoln is parked in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard enters the kitchen with the wood. Bernie and Phil are seated at the kitchen table across fr Mildred. Bernie sips a hot cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: It’s good. Richard adds the wood to the stove and takes a seat at th table next to Mildred. Bernie can’t contain his smile.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I have some really terrific news. The Supreme Court of the United States has agreed to hear our case.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Ooh! Mildred’s hands go to her face, ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: Of course, the state of Virginia will mount their defense, but we are feeling very good about our chances here. You’ve got the full weight of the ACLU behind this.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: It’s a miracle. Mildred grabs Richard’s hand. Richard has not moved, nor smiled.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What’s their defense?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?  88.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Virginia. How are they gonna defend what they done to us?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: I guess we won’t really know until the hearing, but it’s expected they’1l use a defense similar to something they’ve used before.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And what's that? Bernie looks to Phil. They realize they can’t avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: It’s your kids.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Our kids?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Yes. The state of Virginia will argue that it’s unfair to bring children of mixed race into the world. They believe they are bastards. Richard stares at Bernie on this point. It’s rare for him make this much eye contact. Bernie looks down. After a moment, Bernie tries to pick things up.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, as the defendants in this case, you both are allowed to come hear the arguments.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. We won’t need to do that.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Well it’s a very big honor to sit in front of the Supreme Court. Very few people...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. That’s fine. Scuse me. Richard stands and leaves the room. Bernie looks at Mildr who just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Mildred?  156 157 89.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I wouldn't go without him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard stands on the porch smoking a cigarette. He looks out over the cold landscape. Bernie exits the house and takes a place on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: You know, Richard, it’s of course up to you not to attend, but you should know, the Supreme Court only hears maybe 1 out of 400 cases. It’s historic.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr. Cohen. Bernie is stumped.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: Well. Is there anything you want me to tell them, and of course by them I mean the justices of the Supreme Court of the United States? Richard thinks on this for awhile. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tell the judge, tell the judge I love my wife. This strikes Bernie. He understands Richard, possibly for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight breaks through just above the horizon. The snow has all melted. Spring has started, signaled by buds sprouting on the trees. Richard arrives at work alongside other workers. He makes his way to a newly started wall of bricks, sets his work bag and begins taking out his tools for the day.  158 159 160 161 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several cars idle at the curb. Phil, accompanied by his FATHER, climbs out of the first Bernie climbs out of the other. He reaches in for his WIF and leans down to address his Secretary, who is driving.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN
dialogues.text: You’re okay to park? Thanks Martha. Bernie shuts the door. Both cars drive away. He turns and is stopped by the sight in front of him. The Supreme Court of the United States. It’s a massive stone building with expansive white steps leading up to it. It’s both daunting and inspiring. Bernie looks to Phil, who is also pausing to take in the breadth of the building. They look at one another, nervous yet determined, and beg making their way up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred sits in their bedroom at a push pedal sewing mach She runs fabric through, pausing occasionally to inspect stitching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A microphone stands empty atop a lectern. Phil Hirschkop approaches. He looks nervous, but speaks w authority.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP
dialogues.text: May it please the court...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney scales up a tree in the yard. He drags a braided r up with him and begins tying it around a fat limb.  162 91.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You have before you today what we consider the most odious of the segregation laws and the slavery laws, and our view of this law, and we hope to clearly show is that this is a slavery law. Donald and Peggy stare up at their brother in the tree. T rope begins to dangle of its own accord, and they quickly take hold. Swinging, they laugh and shout.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We ask that the Court consider the full spectrum of these laws and not just the criminality, because it’s more than the criminality that’s at point here. Richard patches a board on one of the out buildings. He pauses at the cackling of the children.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL HIRSCHKOP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s the legitimacy of children, the right to inherit land, and many, many rights... He watches them playing at the tree. There couldn’t be a happier place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donald stands on a chair at the sink filling a pitcher wi water. Mildred bounces between the table and the stove. She sets plates, stirs a boiling pot, and guides Donald all at onc

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Just stir it now.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE WARREN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Chief Justice may it please the court... Donald grabs a big spoon and begins stirring as Peggy run and finds a spot nearby to observe. Richard enters with his hand on Sidney’s head. He steers toward the table and they take a seat.  163 164 165 92.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is the danger to the state of Virginia of interracial marriage? Peggy helps Donald carry the heavy pitcher over to the ta Richard leans over in his chair to help make sure it find its way onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is the state of the danger to the people of interracial marriage? Mildred brings a bowl of food over with her and the famil find their respective spots at the table.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE COHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Marriage is a fundamental right. Scooping, pouring, passing. The family eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys’ bedroom is dark, lit only by light from the hal Mildred moves from Donald’s bed to Sidney’s. She straight the covers at his neck. Both boys are asleep. She quietly exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred finds Richard standing in the hallway at Peggy’s door. He watches her through the doorway. She too is asle in her bed. Mildred takes his hand and they walk down the hall. Richa pulls a chain on a bulb turning the hallway dark. They head toward the light spilling from the door of thei own room. They enter, closing the door behind them. The hallway is dark and the house is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer is in full swing, with the oak tree showing bright lush green leaves.  166 167 168 93. It’s hot and Richard swipes a rag across his face and tuc his head back under the hood of one of his rusted cars in front yard. The children play nearby, rolling a tire through the yard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred gathers clothes from a pile on the floor of their bedroom. She lifts a pair of Richard’s pants off a chair begins emptying the pockets. The phone RINGS in the kitchen. Mildred takes her time, adding the pants to her pile and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred enters the kitchen and reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hello? The voices on the line are barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. Hello Mr. Cohen. What’s that? Though the voices are unintelligible, excited shouting ca heard. Mildred smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. I understand. Yes. That’s wonderful news. The voice continues, but Mildred’s mind is already racing She holds her head up, closing her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m here. Okay. Thank you. Mildred hangs up the phone. She pauses there, taking in t moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred steps onto the front porch. She shields her eyes from the sun and scans the yard.  169 170

She finds the children with Richard by the car he’s worki on. Richard chases them with their rolling tire around an around the vehicle. The kids shout. Richard pauses to catch his breath. He looks up to see Mildred on the porch. She’s smiling at him. Richard smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameras roll and flash bulbs pop. A row of reporters stand to one side of a conference room Bernie’s law office. All eyes are on Richard and Mildred. They sit at a table covered with microphones in front of wall lined with shelves of law books. The reporters shout questions.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: (a cacophony ) Mr. Loving? Mrs. Loving? What’s this mean for your family? Do you plan to return to Virginia? Mr. Loving. How does it feel to have the Supreme Court of the United States rule in your favor? Richard squints under the hot lights. He looks to Mildred who is doing the same. In front of the crowd, Richard reaches his arm out and wr it around Mildred’s neck. He pulls her in close, their foreheads touching. Mildred tears in her eyes and Richard is not far behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rhythm of bricks and mortar continue. Brick, then mortar, then brick. Richard is on his knees just having started a course of cinder blocks.  95. Sidney and Donald sit on a pallet of the blocks just behi him. They watch their father’s hands move quickly through the work. Nearby, Mildred sits in the open door of their car. Peggy digs in a cooler at her feet. She produces a bottle of soda and hands it to her mother. Mildred finds an opener and snaps off the cap.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Take that to your father. Peggy runs toward Richard. A foundation has been readied in the field where Richard first proposed to Mildred. Richard works at the edge of that foundation, slowly buil up what will be the front wall of the house. Peggy runs the bottle to her father. He pauses for a sip. Blue sky hangs over it all.

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: Loving v. Virginia made the prohibition of marriage based race unconstitutional. The Supreme Court stated that marriage is an inherent right.

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: Seven years after the Court’s decision, Richard Loving wa killed by a drunk driver. Mildred never remarried and liv the rest of her life in the home Richard built for them.

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: Though shy of press and ever reluctant to be called a her Mildred was interviewed shortly before her death in 2008. She spoke of Richard, saying, “I miss him. He took care o me.” As wind passes through the leaves that look out over the lower field, Mildred walks over to join her family. THE END.
